key_insight: Neural stochastic differential equations that learn state-dependent drift and diffusion can generatively model single-cell dynamics, producing more accurate trajectories and enabling realistic in silico perturbation studies.
problem_solved: How to fit and simulate complex, stochastic cell-state dynamics (including state-dependent noise) from single-cell data to predict developmental trajectories and responses to perturbations.
method: Parameterize drift and diffusion as neural networks inside a stochastic differential equation (neural SDE) to capture state-dependent dynamics and noise.
Train the generative neural SDE on single-cell time-course and snapshot data via likelihood-based/inference techniques to match observed distributions of cell states.
Use the learned SDE to simulate trajectories and perform counterfactual/perturbation experiments by modifying drift/diffusion terms.
impact: Provides AI/ML practitioners a scalable generative framework for realistic dynamical modeling with uncertainty, improving prediction of developmental processes and enabling principled in silico perturbation and causal analyses.
visual_elements: Schematic of the neural SDE pipeline: encoder → learned drift/diffusion neural nets → SDE integrator → simulated cell trajectories
Trajectory plot on a cell-state manifold comparing ground truth, neural SDE reconstructions, and baseline methods
Vector field / heatmap showing learned drift and diffusion magnitudes across the state space
Before/after perturbation panel illustrating counterfactual trajectory simulations under an applied perturbation
paper_title: Learning cell dynamics with neural differential equations
paper_authors: Michael E. Vinyard, Anders W. Rasmussen, Ruitong Li, Allon M. Klein, Gad Getz
